## Why This Is Asked

Tests the ability to translate CKNE health signals into concrete QoS controls for a high-throughput, multi-tenant real-time system.

## Key Concepts

- CKNE health signals (per-tenant latency, queue depth, error rate)
- Per-tenant token-bucket policy and priority tiers
- Minute-by-minute control loop and fairness guarantees
- Payload schemas for health and policy metadata

## Code Example

```javascript
// Minimal payload example
{
  tenantId: "t123",
  ckne: { latencyMs: 45, queueDepth: 12, errorRate: 0.02 },
  policy: { tokens: 120, priority: 1, action: "forward" }
}
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you validate fairness under bursty traffic?
- How would you adapt the policy to changing SLAs without oscillation?

questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests practical CKNE usage in data lineage, balancing auditability with performance across tenants.

## Key Concepts
- CKNE health propagation across ETL hops
- Per-tenant degradation policy with auditability
- Minimal vs full data lineage during health degradation
- Minute-by-minute control loop and testability

## Code Example
```javascript
// Decide whether to drop heavy lineage fields based on CKNE health
function shouldDropLineage(health, thresholdLatency=200, thresholdQueue=1000){
  const degraded = health.latency > thresholdLatency || health.queueDepth > thresholdQueue || health.errorRate > 0.01;
  return degraded;
}
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you test with synthetic tenants and traffic bursts?
- How do you ensure privacy/compliance while preserving essential auditing?
